I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific, prepared by the Economics and Research 
Department, is one of the annual flagship publications of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). 
It provides the latest comprehensive compendium and analysis of trends in economic, social, 
financial, and Millennium Development Goal (MDG) indicators of ADB’s regional members. It 
also contains a special chapter that provides in-depth, data-intensive policy analysis of an 
important  policy  issue. In general,  Key  Indicators  provides  a  strong data  and  information 
support system for evidence-based policy making.1 
 
2.  The proposed technical assistance (TA) will support the preparation of the 47th edition of 
Key Indicators. As it is a premier knowledge product of ADB, and consistently among the top 
two downloaded ADB publications since 2008, its quality must be maintained and its contents 
must be continuously improved. For the special chapter, this requires selecting a topic of policy 
importance to the region and providing a rigorous analysis of associated issues. The design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.2   
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Well-functioning factor markets are a cornerstone of the efficient allocation of resources, 
affecting the pace of innovation, integration, and inclusiveness. The existence of such markets 
is widely believed to have played a crucial role in enabling and facilitating the rapid growth and 
structural transformation experienced by today’s high-income developing member countries 
(DMCs) such as Hong Kong, China; the Republic of Korea; Singapore; and Taipei,China during 
their transition from low to middle and high incomes.   
 
4.  For economies that aim to undertake rapid structural transformation, labor and land use 
(in addition to capital) must shift quickly in response to changing economic conditions and 
policy  stimuli.  These  shifts  occur  simultaneously  across  sectors  (e.g.,  from  traditional 
agriculture to modern manufacturing and services); regions (e.g., from rural to urban regions or 
lagging to dynamic provinces); and firms (e.g., from low productivity, older firms to higher 
productivity, young firms). But such shifts can be especially disruptive for labor, and owners 
and/or  users  of  land  (including  small  agricultural  households).  An  increasingly  important 
challenge for economies in Asia and the Pacific is to design regulatory systems that balance 
the need for flexibility in reallocating factors of production with the need for security or welfare 
of those factors having to adjust.  
 
5.  In  addition  to  the  special  chapter,  the  latest  Key  Indicators  edition  contains 
118 statistical tables of indicators grouped according to various themes, including the MDGs; 
people;  economy  and  output;  money,  finance,  and  prices;  globalization;  transport  and 
communications; energy and electricity; environment; and government and governance. A 
short, nontechnical commentary of selected indicators precedes each of the groups. A review 
of the statistical tables will be carried out to determine whether new indicators need to be 
added and whether some existing indicators may be discontinued. Additionally, the MDG tables 
will have to be modified to reflect new indicators that capture the post-2015 development 
agenda. Similarly, the choice of indicators to be analyzed in the commentaries will be carefully 
considered to reflect the impact of current developments across different themes. 
                                                
1  Key Indicators has four major parts: Part I—the special chapter; Part II—the MDGs; and Part III—the regional 
tables.  A  fourth  part—country  tables containing socioeconomic data  of  ADB developing member  countries, 
Australia, Japan, and New Zealand—is only available online and on USB flash drive. 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 5 November 2014.

2  
 
6.  The message and data contents of Key Indicators must be effectively disseminated to 
its target audience, which includes policy makers, statistical offices, researchers, academics, 
journalists, the private sector, ADB staff, regional and international organizations, and the 
public. Key Indicators is viewed as a credible and valid source for statistics and development 
policy issues in Asia and the Pacific.  
 
III.  THE RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The  impact  of  Key  Indicators  2016  will  be  to  influence  the  environment  in  which 
economic monitoring and policy formulation, investment decisions, and new projects occur, 
especially in ADB’s DMCs. Potential performance targets include citations over the long term to 
the analytical work produced from this product in formal policy documents by development 
partners and DMCs. 
 
8.  The outcome will be that by the end of the project, Key Indicators 2016 will be referred to 
by policy makers and economic researchers within and outside ADB, as well as by the public. 
The improved content of Key Indicators 2016 will provide (i) information on economic trends and 
emerging policy issues that affect the development prospects of DMCs; (ii) high-quality data 
presented in the country, regional, and post-2015 development agenda tables; and (iii) new 
indicators on a specific theme. Potential performance targets would be short-term citations by 
reputable media outlets and invitations to speak on topics covered by Key Indicators. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The TA will support the following key activities of Key Indicators 2016: (i) preparing 
background  papers  and  conducting  data-intensive  research  related  to  the  special  chapter; 
(ii) drafting the special chapter; (iii) updating, compiling, and validating data for the country, 
regional, and post-2015 development agenda tables; (iv) editing, laying out, and printing the 
publication; (v) disseminating the publication; and (vi) analyzing important policy issues related 
to emerging challenges for future special chapters of the Key Indicators series. Following the   
2-year production cycle, initial preparations for Key Indicators 2017 may also be supported 
under this TA. 
 
10.  Keeping  in  view  the  topics  of  previous  Key  Indicators  special  chapters—a 
comprehensive  examination  of  poverty  (Key  Indicators  2014),  structural  transformation 
(Key Indicators  2013),  and  skills  (forthcoming  in  Key  Indicators  2015)—an  in-depth 
examination of the regulations and performance of labor and land markets is proposed for the 
special chapter of Key Indicators 2016. The tentative topic is labor and land regulatory reforms 
for innovation, integration, and inclusive growth. Concerns with economic outcomes in several 
parts of Asia and the Pacific are closely tied to the performance of factor markets. In the case 
of India, for example, labor regulations are held responsible for the lack of regular jobs in 
formal manufacturing, while in the People’s Republic of China, the concern is that the country 
is  moving  too  quickly  from  a  flexible  to  an  inflexible  labor  market.  Similarly,  land-related 
regulations may be holding back the speed of urbanization in several economies in the region, 
and the conversion of land from low to high productivity uses. Improving the functioning of 
factor  markets  is  not  simple,  however.  Labor-related  regulations,  for  example,  have  an 
important role in protecting workers from exploitative working conditions and job-displacing 
economic shocks. Similarly, regulations on land use can improve the bargaining power of small

3
farmers in relation to real estate developers. What is needed is a move to a set of optimal 
regulations  that  balance flexibility  with  the  welfare  of those factors  having  to  adjust. The 
proposed  special  chapter  will  examine  approaches  to  designing  such  regulations  and 
understanding their impact on different population subgroups, gender in particular. It will also 
pay careful attention to the capacity of the state in enforcing these regulations. 
 
11.  The special chapter will rely on several types of analyses. Background studies will 
cover, among others (i) a literature review encompassing the theory and empirical studies of 
how labor and land regulations affect the aggregate economic performance of selected sectors; 
firms’ decisions regarding product lines, employment levels, technology adoption, and location; 
and labor market outcomes; (ii) a review of labor and land regulations across DMCs and 
selected comparator countries outside Asia and the Pacific, and how these compare with what 
theory tells us is optimal from efficiency and equity perspectives; and (iii) country case studies, 
using a mix of qualitative and quantitative methods. The last set of studies will analyze cases 
where actual labor and land use regulations are leading to suboptimal outcomes, and suggest 
how the design and implementation of regulations could be improved.3 These studies will likely 
involve analyses of household, labor force, and enterprise survey data; land registries; or 
administrative records data relevant to labor and land issues. To enhance research quality, the 
Development Indicators and Policy Research Division (ERDI) will seek partnerships with top 
research centers or institutes in the areas of labor and land regulation.4 
 
12.  On the statistics side, the TA will undertake a review of the current set of MDG indicators.  
This is required since the post-2015 development agenda is under discussion and will replace 
the current set of MDG indicators. In addition, based on exploratory analysis, a new set of 
indicators will be introduced on a topic of importance to economic policy making. A promising 
candidate is a specialized set of disaggregated trade indicators that account for the growing 
importance of global value chains in production in the region. Such data are useful for policy 
makers as they allow a much clearer distinction between value added and production data than 
is possible by currently available trade statistics. Significantly, the new trade indicators will draw 
on the outputs of statistical capacity-building work carried out by ADB in the area of national 
accounts. Another possibility in this regard could be specialized indicators around the theme of 
the special chapter. 
 
13.  As part of preparing Key Indicators 2016, workshops and seminars will be held, with 
invitees to include prominent researchers, key government officials, policy makers, and other 
key stakeholders. Workshops and seminars are especially crucial for (i) developing the special 
chapter(s),  (ii)  firming  up  the  initial  findings  of  the  background  research  papers,  and 
(iii) discussing  constraints  on  and  the  general  direction  of  the  special  chapter(s).  Further, 
workshops and seminars may be held to look at the possibility of harmonizing inclusiveness with 
development effectiveness by analyzing economies in Asia and the Pacific that are making 
progress in reducing poverty and inequality. Distinguished experts will be invited to give their 
views  so  that  the  outputs  of  the  workshops  will  be  useful  in  finalizing  the  Key  Indicators 
publications.  Research,  consultations,  and  discussions  with  staff  from  regional  and  other 
                                                
3  The chapter is not expected to cover the issue of land reforms in terms of redistribution of agricultural land, a topic 
that has a voluminous literature.   
4  Collaborations will be explored at a global and regional or country level. In the area of labor regulations, potential 
partners include the International Labour Organization; Centre for Economic Performance, London School of 
Economics, United Kingdom; and the Institute for the Study of Labor at the University of Bonn, Germany. 
Regarding land regulations, a potential partner is the urbanization program of the International Growth Centre. 
Potential partners at the regional or country level will be determined once the countries for which in-depth case 
studies are to be carried out are finalized.

4  
departments  within  ADB  will  also  be  conducted  to  validate  the  relevance  of  the  research 
findings, as well as to identify emerging concerns that can be potential topics for future Key 
Indicators publications. 
 
14.  A series of internal meetings and workshops will be organized to streamline the Key 
Indicators production process. Production bottlenecks to be addressed will include issues such 
as  staff  and  consultant  assignments;  overall  coordination;  development  of  commentaries; 
generation  of  statistical  tables  related  to  country,  region,  and  the  post-2015  development 
agenda; and consultant recruitment. System improvements will be carried out, including the 
interlinked processes involving the statistical database system. The use of Statistical Data and 
Metadata Exchange as an additional platform for regular communications and data exchanges 
will be explored, including sending out Key Indicators questionnaires and receiving replies, and 
for discussion forums including on best practice and methods. 5 Close monitoring of the Key 
Indicators  process  will  mitigate  the  risk  of  unforeseen  circumstances  that  may  affect  the 
production schedule. 
   
15.  To improve the quality of Key Indicators, new regional aggregations may be introduced 
in the statistical tables. Various aggregations are currently available but are limited to a few 
indicators.  Compiling  aggregates  using  transparent,  consistent,  and  sound  methods  and 
practices will provide additional value to users. However, this may involve looking at different 
classifications and aggregation practices used in Key Indicators in light of recent socioeconomic 
developments in Asia and the Pacific and practices of other international organizations, and this 
may raise complex issues. The TA will support the development of methodologies to produce 
the aggregations. 
 
16.  To ensure accuracy, coherence, and consistency of approach across the different parts 
of  Key  Indicators,  the  knowledge  products  will  undergo  stringent  editing  following  ADB’s 
Handbook of Style and Usage.6 Experienced international economics or manuscript editors will 
help  prepare  the  publication’s  special  chapter(s)  and  highlights.  Copy  editors  will  edit  the 
regional tables, country tables, post-2015 development agenda tables, the definitions, and front 
parts of the documents.  
 
17.   The Key Indicators publications will be widely disseminated in coordination with ADB’s 
Department of External Relations. Dissemination will start with an international media launch 
followed by seminar presentations to key government officials, businesspeople, academia, and 
other research groups. Concurrently, the publications will be uploaded to the ADB website. 
Background papers will be published separately in ADB’s working paper series, the Asian 
Development Review, or other media at a later date. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The TA is estimated to cost $750,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-V). Appendix 2 presents the cost estimates and 
financing plan.

initiative supported by the Bank for International Settlements, European Central Bank, Eurostat, International 
Monetary Fund, Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, United Nations, and the World Bank to 
harmonize and standardize exchange of statistical information.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  ADB will be the executing agency for this TA. ERDI will be the TA supervising unit. ERDI 
will coordinate with other ADB units (regional departments and resident mission offices) and 
statistical partners in ADB regional members in undertaking the activities for this TA. The project 
will be implemented over 25 months, beginning December 2014 until its targeted completion on 
31 December 2016. 
 
20.  The Key Indicators publication is produced by a team consisting of ERDI international, 
national, and administrative staff with support from international and national consultants. For 
Key Indicators 2016, an estimated 15 person-months of international consultancy services and 
119 person-months of national consultancy services will be needed for the entire production 
process, i.e., for the special chapter, the statistical tables (country, post-2015 development 
agenda, and regional tables), special pilot indicators or datasets, and other developmental 
activities related to improving data quality and promoting effective dissemination of findings.  
 
21.  Consulting services are required to develop the different parts of Key Indicators. For the 
statistical tables, the international consultants will review data issues pertaining to the statistical 
tables  published  in  Key  Indicators,  and  propose  viable  imputation  procedures for  selected 
important indicators compiled in the publication. The national consultants will assist in preparing 
the statistical tables and commentaries, layout of text and tables, and manuscript or copy editing. 
 
22.  For the special  chapter, the  international  and national  consultants  will  work  on  the 
analysis and write-up for a theme of interest (to be finalized), prepare background reports and 
original research related to the theme, and provide some manuscript and economics editing, 
while  the  national  consultants  will  assist  in  data gathering,  data  cleaning  and  updating of 
indicators and further research on the indicators, layout of text and tables, and manuscript and 
copy editing. Surveys may be conducted in selected DMCs as necessary to enhance and 
improve the relevance of the analysis. 
 
23.  International and national consultants will also be used for developing a new set of 
indicators  on  a  topic  of  importance to  economic  policy  making.  Resource  persons  will  be 
engaged for the workshops to be conducted, e.g., Key Indicators workshops for the special 
chapters and subregional workshops for the statistical tables. Travel of ADB staff participating in 
related workshops, conferences, or seminars as resource persons and providing administrative 
and support services may also be supported, in accordance with the appropriate administrative 
guideline. 
 
24.  The outline terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3 and the publication 
outline is in Appendix 4. The consultants will be hired as individuals and will be engaged in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to 
time).  Disbursements  under  the  TA  will  be  made  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
25.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis for 
Key Indicators for Asia and the Pacific 2016, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.        Economists and Subject Matter Specialists (international, 11.5 person-months total, 
intermittent, 4–5 consultants)  
1.   The  consultants  should  have  a  strong  background  in  development  economics, 
economics or other related subjects. They should have at least a master’s degree in their field of 
expertise and have more than 10 years of relevant work experience. The consultants should 
also have expertise or interests in Asia and the Pacific economies. He or she will carry out the 
following activities: 
 (i)  conduct empirical research and surveys, if necessary, on how selected policies 
and institutional frameworks, especially those relating to labor regulations and 
land  regulations,  influence  firms’  decisions  on  employment,  production, 
technology adoption, and location; 
(ii)  compare  and  contrast  actual  versus  optimal  labor  and  land  regulations  that 
balance the need for flexibility for firms with the welfare of those factors or factor 
owners;   
(iii)  compare and contrast actual versus optimal labor and land regulations in terms 
of their impacts by gender; 
(iv)  investigate approaches to designing optimal regulations, paying careful attention 
to the capacity of the state in enforcing these regulations;   
(v)  investigate features of firms with higher growth potential and recommend more 
effective policies to encourage firm growth, which in turn create more good jobs; 
and 
(vi)  provide advice on the direction of research for the special chapter and potentially 
contribute subsection(s) to the special chapter, with the following specific tasks:  
(a)  review  draft  outline  of  the  special  chapter  prepared  by  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) staff, and provide comments and suggestions 
for its finalization; 
(b)  attend  workshop(s)  and  provide  comments  and  suggestions  for  the 
finalization of background papers; 
(c)  provide advice to authors of the background papers as required; and 
(d)  draft a paper that will serve as one of the key highlights in the special 
chapter to be presented in one or two workshops. 
 
2.   The output will include background papers for the special chapter. 
 
B.        Economists,  Statisticians,  or  Data  Specialists  (national,  36  person-months  total, 
intermittent, 12 consultants)  
3.   The national consultants should have well-rounded knowledge of features of firms and 
either labor markets or land markets in their countries. They should also be knowledgeable 
about  sources  of good  data,  and  have  the  ability  to  access  these  data  or  be  capable of 
collecting the necessary data through survey techniques. They should also have the ability to 
analyze the data using statistical and econometric techniques. They should have at least a 
master’s degree in their field of expertise and have more than 10 years of relevant work 
experience. The tasks assigned are as follows: 
 
(i)  describe  major  patterns  and  trends  on  the  production,  employment,  and 
locational  choice  of  firms  in  their  country;  or  perform  analytical  work  on  a 
secondary dataset or dataset collected by conducting own survey;

D.  Economics and Statistics Specialists (national, 70 person-months total, 10 consultants) 
8.  The  economics  and  statistics  national  consultant  should  have  (i)  a  background  in 
economics or statistics, experience working in statistics or research analysis, and at least 
3 years of relevant work experience; (ii) the technical and analytical skills required for the project; 
(iii) a good understanding of official statistics and national statistical systems; (iv) advanced 
knowledge and proficiency in using Microsoft Excel, Microsoft Word, and other relevant software; 
(v)  experience  in  performing  automated  business  processes;  (vi)  due  diligence  in  data 
compilation and validation; (vii) good writing skills; and (viii) creativity in presenting statistical 
graphs. Tasks assigned are as follows: 
(i)  gather, process, compile, and validate survey data and statistics from assigned 
regional members and other sources; 
(ii)  generate, review, and finalize assigned statistical tables under the guidance of 
ERDI international staff and the Key Indicators coordinator using applications of 
the statistical database system; 
(iii)  study  the  assigned  themes,  and  together  with  their  ERDI  staff  counterpart, 
analyze the available statistics data and other information; 
(iv)  suggest or create statistical graphs in the analysis of commentaries; 
(v)  review and update the statistical definitions and concepts used in the preparation 
of Key Indicators; 
(vi)  review or revise the statistics and write-ups on commentaries; 
(vii)  implement the new aggregation methods;  
(viii)  participate in integrating the report in the Key Indicators publication;  
(ix)  draft a paper based on original empirical research (using household survey data 
and statistical indicators) on a selected theme (to be determined) that will serve 
as the basis for the introductory chapter of the Key Indicators special section 
from the perspective of inclusive growth in developing Asia;  
(x)  develop policy prescriptions that are needed for inclusive growth for the selected 
theme;  
(xi)  discuss regularly with the project officer any issues encountered in drafting the 
paper; present the draft paper in the ERDI seminar series or in other workshops 
as  needed,  to  solicit  further  comments  for  improvements  and  fine-tune  the 
methodology and overall paper quality;  
(xii)  finalize the draft report based on solicited comments; and  
(xiii)  perform other related technical and administrative tasks as may be assigned by 
the Key Indicators coordinator. 
 
9.   The  output  will  include  Key  Indicators  questionnaires,  country  tables,  Millennium 
Development Goals (MDGs) or post-2015 tables, regional tables, and charts and figures in the 
write-ups, highlights, and presentation materials. 
 
E.        Trade Data Specialist (national, 12 person-months total, continuous, 1 consultant)  
10.  The trade data specialist should have a strong background in economics and statistics,
